GeneralExplanationGrp.MediumExplanationTxt: VARTAN GREGORIAN, PRESIDENT/TRUSTEE- COMPENSATION $784,428 INCLUDES $9,428 REPRESENTING INCOME DISTRIBUTED FROM EARNINGS ON ACCOUNT HOLDINGS UNDER THE CORPORATION'S FLEX-OP PLAN.- RECEIVED $50,000 HOUSING ALLOWANCE.AMY GUTMANN, ANNA PALACIO AND NORMAN PEARLSTINE COMPLETED THEIR TERMS OF SERVICE AT THE DECEMBER 5, 2013 BOARD MEETING.JARED COHON AND JUDY WOODRUFF BEGAN THEIR TERMS OF SERVICE AT THE DECEMBER 5, 2013 BOARD MEETING.JANET ROBINSON AND ANNE TATLOCK BEGAN THEIR TERM OF SERVICE AT THE MARCH 6, 2014 BOARD MEETING.

CARNEGIE CORPORATION OF NEW YORK (CC) WAS FOUNDED IN 1911 FOR THE ADVANCEMENT AND DIFFUSION OF KNOWLEDGE AND UNDERSTANDING. CC FULFILLS ITS CHARTER PRIMARILY BY GIVING GRANTS TO ORGANIZATIONS IN THE PROGRAM AREAS SELECTED BY ITS PRESIDENT AND BOARD OF TRUSTEES. (SEE STATEMENT 20 FOR IDENTIFICATION OF THE CURRENT AREAS OF CONCENTRATION.) IN ADDITION TO MAKING GRANTS, CC ENCOURAGES STAFF MEMBERS TO GIVE FREELY OF THEIR TIME TO ASSIST OTHER NON PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS AND GOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES INVOLVED IN PUBLIC SERVICE. THIS IS ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH SERVICE ON BOARDS AND ADVISORY COMMITTEES OF OTHER INSTITUTIONS, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, RESEARCH, PUBLICATION AND DISSEMINATION OF EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS AND THE CONDUCT OF EDUCATIONAL CONFERENCES, MEETINGS AND SEMINARS.A) TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO GRANTEES AND OTHER CHARITABLE ORGANIZATIONS: $559,982THIS AMOUNT REPRESENTS SALARY AND OVERHEAD ALLOCATIONS OF PROGRAM STAFF FOR TIME SPENT ADVISING GRANTEES AND OTHER CHARITABLE ORGANIZATIONS ON A VARIETY OF SUBJECTS INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, OBTAINING ADDITIONAL FUNDING FROM OTHER SOURCES, REDUCING OPERATING EXPENSES, COMPLYING WITH GOVERNMENT REGULATION, AND MAINTAINING ACCURATE FINANCIAL RECORDS.B) CONDUCTING CONFERENCES AND MEETINGS: 49,116CC CONDUCTS SEVERAL MEETINGS PER YEAR IN EACH OF ITS PROGRAM AREAS THAT BRING TOGETHER PARTICIPANTS FROM VARIOUS ACADEMIC DISCIPLINES, AND THE PUBLIC AND PRIVATE SECTORS, TO EXCHANGE IDEAS AND FORMULATE SOLUTIONS OR METHODS OF ARRIVING AT SOLUTIONS TO PROBLEMS IN THEIR AREA OF EXPERTISE. THE MEETINGS BENEFIT THESE INDIVIDUALS AND ULTIMATELY THE COMMUNITIES THEY SERVE.C) PUBLICATION AND DISSEMINATION OF EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS: $2,929,138ARTICLES, BOOKS AND OTHER READING MATERIAL, GENERATED FROM THE MEETINGS MENTIONED ABOVE, FROM CARNEGIE-SUPPORTED GRANTEES AND CARNEGIE STAFF, ARE REGULARLY PRODUCED AND DISTRIBUTED BY CC TO THE GENERAL PUBLIC AND TO THOSE INDIVIDUALS MOST DIRECTLY INTERESTED IN THEIR CONTENTS. THE CORPORATION MAINTAINS A FILE OF NAMES AND ADDRESSES TO FACILITATE THE DISSEMINATION PROGRAM. D) OTHER: $180,756THE MAJORITY OF THIS CATEGORY REPRESENTS THE ALLOCATION OF SALARIES, BENEFITS, AND OVERHEAD FOR STAFF WHO CONTRIBUTE PORTIONS OF THEIR TIME TO THE ADMINISTRATION OF CORPORATION-SPONSORED ACTIVITY: FOR ADVANCING THE RECOMMENDATIONS OF THE OPPORTUNITY EQUATION: TRANSFORMING MATHEMATICS AND SCIENCE EDUCATION FOR CITIZENSHIP AND THE GLOBAL ECONOMY AND PROGRAM DISSEMINATION FUND. E) SERVICE ON BOARDS OR ADVISORY COMMITTEES: $306,763THE AMOUNT REPRESENTS THE COST TO SUPPORT THE SERVICE OF THE CORPORATION'S STAFF ON BOARDS OR ADVISORY COMMITTEES OF OTHER CHARITABLE ORGANIZATIONS.TOTAL DIRECT CHARITABLE ACTIVITIES: $4,025,755

THE CHARTER OF THE CORPORATION PROVIDES THAT ALL FUNDS ARE TO BE USED TO PROMOTE "THE ADVANCEMENT AND DIFFUSION OF KNOWLEDGE AND UNDERSTANDING." GRANTS MUST BE BROADLY EDUCATIONAL IN NATURE, BUT THEY NEED NOT BE LIMITED TO THE FORMAL EDUCATIONAL SYSTEM OR TO EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTIONS. THE FOUNDATION MAKES IT A POLICY TO SELECT A FEW AREAS IN WHICH TO CONCENTRATE ITS GRANTS OVER A PERIOD OF YEARS. THE CORPORATION CURRENTLY OPERATES GRANT PROGRAMS IN FOUR BROAD AREAS. THE FOUR AREAS ARE EDUCATION, INTERNATIONAL PEACE AND SECURITY, INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT, AND STRENGTHENING U.S. DEMOCRACY. THE CORPORATION ACCEPTS REQUESTS FOR FUNDING AT ALL TIMES OF THE YEAR. THERE ARE NO APPLICATION DEADLINES.GRANT DECISIONS ARE BASED PRIMARILY ON THE INFORMATION PROVIDED BY GRANTSEEKERS IN THE CORPORATION'S OWN DETAILED PROPOSALS FORMATS. ONLY PROPOSALS PRESENTED IN THE CORPORATION'S FORMAT WILL BE CONSIDERED FOR FUNDING. GRANTSEEKERS WHO WOULD LIKE TO APPROACH THE FOUNDATION WITH A PRELIMINARY REQUEST FOR FUNDING ARE ENCOURAGED TO SUBMIT A LETTER OF INQUIRY. IF THE PROJECT DESCRIBED IN THE LETTER FITS THE FOUNDATION'S GUIDELINES, THE SENDER WILL BE CONTACTED AND ASKED TO SUBMIT A PROPOSAL IN THE CORPORATION'S FORMAT. A REQUEST TO SUBMIT A PROPOSAL IS NOT AN INDICATION OF THE CORPORATION'S INTENTION OR COMMITMENT TO AWARD A GRANT.A LETTER OF INQUIRY, NOT TO EXCEED FIVE PAGES, SHOULD CONCISELY DESCRIBE THE PROJECT, ITS AIMS, ITS SIGNIFICANCE, ITS DURATION AND THE AMOUNTS OF FUNDS REQUIRED. THE INQUIRY SHOULD BE SENT TO ELLEN BLOOM, CORPORATE SECRETARY, CARNEGIE CORPORATION OF NEW YORK, 437 MADISON AVENUE, NEW YORK, NY 10022. HER TELEPHONE NUMBER IS (212) 371-3200.THE CORPORATION DOES NOT MAKE GRANTS FOR CONSTRUCTION OR MAINTENANCE OF FACILITIES OR ENDOWMENTS. IT DOES NOT MAKE PROGRAM-RELATED INVESTMENTS.THE CORPORATION DOES NOT GENERALLY MAKE GRANTS TO INDIVIDUALS. THE CORPORATION USUALLY CONSIDERS ONLY THOSE PROJECTS THAT HAVE THE POTENTIAL FOR WIDE-SPREAD NATIONAL OR INTERNATIONAL IMPACT. IT DOES NOT GENERALLY MAKE GRANTS TO LOCAL OR REGIONAL COMMUNITY SERVICE ORGANIZATIONS.
